bibl.title: Letter from Christopher Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 23, 1902

div1.p: Christopher Reed provides a story of young Walter Reed in Brooklyn, where he was frustrated by malpractice in the medical profession.

div1.head: Letter from Christopher Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 23, 1902
div1.opener:
C1
B3
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Dec 23/02
C. REED
ATTORNEY AND COUNSELOR AT LAW
317 COMMERCIAL BUILDING
ST. LOUIS, MO.
My dear Dr
div1.p:
My sister & brother, the
former at Ashland Va,
Mrs. Laura Blincoe, and
the latter at #578 Clay St. Lynchburg
Va Rev. James C Reed, will
in all probability send you
some incidents in his life
to illustrate his high character.

I forgot to speak of one
incident which I will now
mention, if you care to use it.
When on the Board of Health of Brooklyn
Nyk a Dr called on him (W) (in his
capacity as Inspector) to report the death
of a child, but was so grossly ignorant
that he was unable to describe the symptoms;
When I returned from my Law office in ev'g
I found him W depressed very much
I enquired what the cause
was & he said: “To-day an elegant
equippage with coachman and
footman stopped in front of
my office & a finely dressed gentleman
came in & said he was -- Dr ------ and
desired to report the death of a child patient-
He was so ignorant that he couldn't
use correctly medical nomenclature.
He stumbled along but could not
adequately state its symptoms- I then
asked, if he didn't think it was such
a disease using the latin words;
and he answered “yes” &positively
repeated the words backward; Now this
man has the leading practice in
this part of Brooklyn -- & he is a firstclass
quack; I am disgusted; I shall quit
the profession” -- I said to hims s that
such fellows were due to natural
causes like bed-bugs; that onethired on
the ignorance of the people & the stress
upon the slovenliness of the housekeeper;
and I then quoted to him Lord Brown's famous
remark about the people- He laughed
& said; “Well I guess I will hold on” --

My sister wrote that he kept an Army Diary but that
he lost it- I forgot to say that he was 18 when
he graduated at Bellevue & that his diploma
was witheld until he was 21- That was the rule of this College

I presume Mrs. Dr Reed will send you
my sketch soon -- She now has it- I have a copy of it
This letter for reference you can retain-
